Q. 4) The force of mortality ‘mu(x)’ for a particular group of life can be calculated using the 
formula as A*B^x; where A=0.00002; B=exp(c); c=0.09; x denotes the age of the life.


i) Write down a formula for mu(x) in R and calculate the value of mu(50). 
ii) If survival probability px can be approximated as [exp(-mu(x+0.5))], calculate the 
probability that a life aged 50, will remain alive after 10 years. 
iii) Create a table of mortality rate qx for ages between 40 to 50. 

---
Page 8 of 9
Solution 4: 
i)
A=0.00002 
C=0.09 
B=exp(C) 
mu<-function(x) { 
 A * B^x 
} 
mu(50) 
> mu(50) 
[1] 0.001800343 
 [5] 
ii)
px<-function(x) { 
 exp(-mu(x+0.5)) 
} 
x=50 
npx=1 
for(t in 1:10) 
{alive=px(x+t-1); npx=npx*alive} 
npx 
> npx 
[1] 0.9712341 

---

===============================

iii)

```{r}
xlist=seq(40,50) 
qx<-function(x) { 
 1-px(x) 
} 
qlist=sapply(xlist,qx) 
```
